entry.title: Kindness: Bunnies
entry.content:
…One morning, when maybe going out to fish, I encountered a bunny. The bunny had not had a good day. Apparently it argued with a cat or other predator, and although it (or maybe I) convinced that other animal to go away, the other animal had done some serious damage in the process. A rear leg was not really attached anymore, and blood was coming from many different parts of the bunny. But the bunny was alive. It was incredibly cute.

I picked up the bunny, and held it. I had never had something so small, cute, and cuddly in my hands before. I so wanted to keep this incredible source of happiness as my pet. Too have my own little bunny, which I would take care of and it would make me happy.

But the extent of the injuries made it obvious that this was not to be….

entry.title: Love: Programming
entry.content:
I am a professional programmer, which means I get paid to read and write software. Fortunately, I love to read and write software, so I am in the right business. Programming is amazingly powerful now that robots, the Internet, and almost everything has some kind of program inside it. I started programming when programming was simpler, which made it easier for me to learn. And I am going to teach you how to program by going back to something similarly simple and even tangible.

For those who think they should scurry to the next chapter out of fear, please fear not. At worse I will fail. I am pretty good at that, but sometimes I don’t. And for those who think they know the art of programming too well to stay, please don’t scurry away, quite yet, either. For I am not going to just teach you how to program, I am going to teach you how to program in the only true programming language. This is not just a great programming language; it is truly what “The Matrix” is made of. It is the language of the machines and the only true programming language to those machines. It is named “Machine Language”. Sadly, computer people are commonly very rigorous and not very creative about how they name things.

To learn the one true language, you will need some playing cards and a desk or relatively empty space in which to work.

entry.title: Love: Nature
entry.content:
Nature has an incredible influence on humans. Yosemite, the Grand Canyon, Bryce, Tahoe, Muir Woods, and many other natural wonders have heavily influenced my family and me. They are amazing. You need to see them. If you have a chance, put this book down right now and make the reservation. Then pick it back up: you can bring it with you.

Rebecca and I are especially enchanted by Yosemite. It is awesome, and its awe changes with the seasons, and with the shape of our family. Rebecca and I went several times when we were young. We have sat on the top of the fissures staring down several thousand feet at the beautiful valley floor beneath us. Today, just thinking about it, makes me shudder. I don’t think at my current age I could sit there and look down. Too many images of accidentally “taking a leap” fly through my head.

Rebecca and I have also tried to hike up the mist trail to Nevada falls in the winter, but were ultimately repelled by snow and ice. And one Spring, our whole family caught giant snowflakes that poured down on us in a freakish April snowstorm. Yosemite is amazing. And so are all the other national treasures. Sometimes politicians do the right thing.

entry.title: Site Launch!
entry.content: Earlier today I decided that I should have a site for the book. After doing so many startups, and with some great services out there, launching the IT (or Infrastructure) of a new company is incredibly easy. A web site is among the easiest of the infrastructure to set up. I purchased the domain name, pointed it at github.io, cloned and customized Octopress, and after a few ‘rake generate; rake deploy’ edit cycles, the book proposal and this blog posting were up and alive.
